FR-02 The system shall send a verification email to confirm the User user's email address before account activation.
FR-03 The system shall allow users to log in using their User registered email and password.
FR-04 The system shall provide a mechanism for users to User recover their password via email.

FR-06 The system shall allow users to view other users' profiles User with appropriate privacy controls.
FR-07 The system shall provide a search function for students to User find tutors based on subjects, availability, and ratings.
FR-08 The system shall allow users to filter and sort tutor search User results by price, rating, and experience.
FR-09 The system shall allow tutors to set their available time User slots.
FR-10 The system shall allow students to book sessions with User tutors based on their availability.
FR-12 The system shall provide a virtual classroom environment System with video, audio, and chat functionalities.
FR-13 The system shall include an interactive whiteboard and System screen sharing for learning.
FR-14 The system shall allow tutoring sessions to be recorded System and stored for later review.
FR-15 The system shall support payment processing via credit System card, debit card, and other common payment methods.
FR-16 The system shall generate invoices for each booked and System completed session.
FR-17 The system shall implement a refund policy for cancelled Business sessions.
FR-18 The system shall allow students to submit reviews and User ratings for tutors after each session.
FR-19 The system shall provide moderators with tools to System manage and moderate reviews.
FR-20 The system shall send email notifications for booking System confirmations, reminders, and password recovery.
FR-21 The system shall provide in-app notifications for real- System time updates.
FR-22 The system shall generate reports on sessions booked, Business completed, and tutor earnings.
FR-23 The system shall provide analytics on tutor performance Business based on student feedback.

2.2.1 Login Enables all users to securely access the system using their registered account credentials.

The module manages session initiation and termination, ensuring that users are properly authenticated before accessing other system functions. It also supports password recovery by allowing users to request a reset link and update their credentials. This module serves as the primary gateway for students, tutors, and administrators to interact with the system.

2.2.2 Registration Handles the creation of new user accounts and validates them through an email verification process. This module collects required information including name, email, and password, and stores it in the system database. It sends a verification link or code to the provided email address and grants full system access upon successful verification, ensuring that all registered accounts use valid and active email addresses.

2.2.5 Enrollment Manages the process of course registration for students. This module receives enrollment requests, verifies course availability, and prevents duplicate enrollments. It supports cancellation of enrollments and confirms successful registration. It also links confirmed enrollments to the payment module for transaction processing, ensuring accurate records and seamless workflow integration.

2.2.6 Videotelephony Facilitates real-time virtual tutoring sessions between students and tutors. This module supports starting and joining live video sessions, requesting device access for camera and microphone, and ending sessions upon completion. It enables session recording upon request and securely stores the recordings for future reference or review. Integrated with the notifications module to send session reminders and real-time alerts.

2.2.7 Payment Manages all financial transactions within the system. This module handles payment creation, confirmation, and processing of refunds. It generates and provides payment invoices to users and validates payment details before approval. Sensitive payment data is encrypted to ensure compliance with PDPA and PCI DSS requirements, protecting user financial information from unauthorized access.

2.2.10 Search Enables tutor discovery by enabling users to system targeted searches based on course, qualifications, ratings, and availability. This module provides filtering and sorting capabilities, receive detailed tutor profiles, and highlights top-rated tutors to improve course selection efficiency.
2.3 Design and Implementation Constraints The Online Tutoring System must adhere to several constraints to ensure it is feasible, maintainable, and compliant with industry standards.
• Data Protection and Privacy: Comply with Malaysia's Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) 2010, ensuring user consent, data access, deletion options, and data encryption.
• Educational Standards: Adhere to best practices in educational data privacy and security as recommended by local educational authorities.
• Accessibility: Follow Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 to ensure usability by individuals with disabilities.
• Scalability: Design the system to handle increasing users and sessions without compromising performance. Use scalable cloud services and efficient database management.
• Performance: Optimize code, data handling, and network infrastructure to deliver high performance with minimal latency, especially during live sessions.
• Time: Follow the project timeline to meet launch deadlines, requiring efficient project management and regular progress reviews.
• Human Resources: Availability of skilled developers, designers, and support staff may limit development pace and scope. Consider outsourcing to mitigate this constraint.
2.3.4 Usability Constraints Usability considerations include:
• User Interface (UI) Design: Provide an intuitive and user-friendly interface for users with varying technical expertise. Ensure clear navigation, responsive design, and accessible
2.3.5 Security Constraints Security measures include:
• Data Security: Encrypt all user data in transit and at rest to protect against unauthorized access. Conduct regular security audits and vulnerability assessments.
• Incident Response: Have a defined incident response plan to address security breaches or system failures promptly, including procedures for data recovery, user notification, and system restoration.
• Consistency and Responsiveness: Ensure a cohesive look and feel across the platform with a fully responsive design for desktops, tablets, and smartphones.
• Scalability and Performance: Design the interface to support future expansion and optimize for fast loading times and smooth interactions, especially during live sessions.
• Resource Availability: Financial, human, and technical resources will be available throughout the project.
• Third-Party Services: Third-party services (cloud hosting, payment gateways) will be reliable and uphold SLAs.
• User Adoption: Positive adoption rate driven by effective marketing and platform usability.
• Infrastructure and Hosting: Platform performance depends on the chosen cloud service provider (AWS, Google Cloud, Microsoft Azure).
• Third-Party Integrations: Reliance on third-party integrations for payment processing, real-time communication, and data analytics.
• Development Tools and Technologies: Availability and stability of development tools, frameworks, and libraries are crucial.

3.2 Selected Elicitation Techniques I. Interviews  Justification:

Interviews allow direct, in-depth communication with stakeholders, enabling clarification of requirements and exploration of needs that stakeholders may not initially articulate. This is suitable for understanding expectations from students, tutors, and parents.

Conduct one-on-one semi-structured interviews with each stakeholder group that 30 minutes each. Questions will focus on system usability, essential features, and pain points with existing tutoring methods.

Reviewing existing online tutoring system, competitor feature lists, and relevant educational guidelines helps identify industry-standard practices and compliance requirements. This helps to reduces the risk of overlooking critical functions and ensuring the competitiveness against other competitor.
Analyse user manuals, competitor websites, and online reviews to extract best practices, identify common pain points, and compile a checklist of essential and desirable features.
- 24/7 booking system with real-time availability updates.
- Automated payment processing with multiple gateway options (Stripe/PayPal).

Functional requirements specify the essential services the system must provide, while non-functional requirements describe characteristics such as performance, usability, security, and reliability. All requirements are based on validated stakeholder input and serve as the basis for system design, development, and testing.

Requirement The system shall ensure that the response time for any user action does not exceed 2 seconds under normal load conditions that for 1000 concurrent users.
The system shall be able to scale to support up to 10,000 concurrent users without performance degradation that does not exceed 5 seconds loading time.
The system shall be capable of handling at least 1,000 transactions per minute during peak usage times.
The system shall provide a user-friendly interface that is intuitive and easy to navigate for users of all technical skill levels.
The system shall comply with WCAG 2.1 AA standards to ensure accessibility for users with disabilities.
The system shall provide comprehensive user documentation and help resources, including FAQs, tutorials, and customer support.
The system shall have an uptime of 99.9% to ensure it is always available to users.
The system shall perform daily backups of all critical data and provide a recovery mechanism to restore data in case of failure.
The system shall be designed to handle and recover from hardware and software failures with minimal impact on users.
The system shall encrypt all sensitive data, both at rest and in transit, using industry-standard encryption protocols.

5. Risk and Validation Summary Key risks that may affect the delivery, quality, or usability of the Online Tutoring System are identified and assessed in this section. Validation strategies are proposed to confirm that each requirement is satisfied under expected operational conditions. Special attention is given to requirements-related risks, such as scalability, security, and integration dependencies.
5.1 Requirements Evaluation I. Consistency All functional and non-functional requirements have been reviewed for internal consistency. No conflicting requirements were identified.
 Requirements related to payment (FR-15, FR-16, FR-17) align with security and compliance requirements (NFR-10, NFR-11, NFR-12).
 Notification requirements (FR-20, FR-21) are consistent with usability and accessibility requirements (NFR-04, NFR-05).
 Performance constraints (NFR-01 to NFR-03) do not contradict usability or security requirements.

II. Completeness The requirements cover all critical aspects of the Online Tutoring System, including user registration, authentication, scheduling, tutoring sessions, payments, analytics, and system administration.
 Non-functional requirements (NFR-01 to NFR-19) define performance, usability, reliability, security, maintainability, portability, and compliance attributes.
 Areas for future refinement include more detailed metrics for live video streaming performance and tutor recommendation algorithms.

 Technical feasibility: All key features (video conferencing, payment integration, calendar sync) can be implemented using existing technologies such as WebRTC, Stripe/PayPal APIs, and Google Calendar API.
Mitigation Strategy Implement real-time availability checks with booking locks to prevent simultaneous reservations.
Integrate multiple payment gateways, add retry mechanisms, and implement reconciliation processes.
Enforce encryption, multi- factor authentication, access control, and conduct regular compliance audits.
Add moderation tools, allow tutors to appeal ratings, and use weighted/recent reviews in scoring.

Interview 1: Student  Q: What challenges do you face in current online tutoring platforms?
 A: It's difficult to find tutors available in my time zone. The system should allow me to check tutor availability in real-time.
Interview 2: Tutor  Q: What problems do you face when providing tutoring online?
 A: Payment delays are common. I want an automated and secure payment system.
Interview 3: Parent  Q: What concerns do you have when your child uses tutoring platforms?
 A: I want to track my child's progress and make sure payments are secure.
 A: A dashboard showing session history, tutor performance, and spending.
Interview 4: Admin  Q: What challenges do you face when managing the platform?
 A: It's hard to moderate reviews and handle inappropriate content.
 A: Tools to flag and remove harmful reviews quickly, plus automated reports.

Third-Party Services: Third-party services (cloud hosting, payment gateways) will be reliable and uphold SLAs.

2.2.1 Login Enables all users to securely access the system using their registered account credentials.

The module manages session initiation and termination, ensuring that users are properly authenticated before accessing other system functions. It also supports password recovery by allowing users to request a reset link and update their credentials. This module serves as the primary gateway for students, tutors, and administrators to interact with the system.

Role: Student, Administrators Facilitates real-time virtual tutoring sessions between students and tutors. This module supports starting and joining live video sessions, requesting device access for camera and microphone, and ending sessions upon completion. It enables session recording upon request and securely stores the recordings for future reference or review. Integrated with the notifications module to send session reminders and real-time alerts.

This module enables the creation of chat rooms, exchange of real-time messages, retrieval of timely and organized interaction between users and the support team for both technical and service-related matters.

2.2.10 Search Enables tutor discovery by enabling users to system targeted searches based on course, qualifications, ratings, and availability. This module provides filtering and sorting capabilities, receive detailed tutor profiles, and highlights top-rated tutors to improve course selection efficiency.
The Online Tutoring System must adhere to several constraints to ensure it is feasible, maintainable, and compliant with industry standards.
Human Resources: Availability of skilled developers, designers, and support staff may Usability considerations include:
Data Security: Encrypt all user data in transit and at rest to protect against unauthorized access. Conduct regular security audits and vulnerability assessments.
Scalability and Performance: Design the interface to support future expansion and optimize for fast loading times and smooth interactions, especially during live sessions.

The successful design, development, and implementation of the Online Tutoring System are based on several assumptions and dependencies. This section outlines these key factors to ensure that all stakeholders have a clear understanding of the conditions under which the project will be executed.
User Access to Technology: Users will have necessary hardware (computers, tablets, smartphones) and stable internet connections.
Technical Skills: Users will have basic technical skills to use the platform.
Compliance and Regulations: Platform will comply with current regulations in Malaysia and Southeast Asia.
Resource Availability: Financial, human, and technical resources will be available throughout the project.
Third-Party Services: Third-party services (cloud hosting, payment gateways) will be reliable and uphold SLAs.
The following dependencies must be managed to ensure the project's success:

All requirements are based on validated stakeholder input and serve as the basis for system design, development, and testing.

As a student, I want to create an account with my name, email, and password so that I can access the system.
As a user, I want to log in with my email and password so that I can access my dashboard.
As a user, I want to reset my password via email so that I can regain access if I forget it.
As a student, I want to update my profile with subjects of interest so that tutors can better match my needs.
As a tutor, I want to update my profile with subjects of expertise so that students can find me easily.
As a student, I want to search tutors by subject and availability so that I can find the result I want.
As a student, I want to filter tutors by rating and price so that I can choose the best option for my budget.
As a tutor, I want to set my available time slots so that students can book sessions with me.
As a student, I want to book a session based on a tutor's available time so that I can plan my learning schedule.
As a student, I want to join a virtual classroom with video, audio, and chat so that I can learn effectively.
As a tutor, I want to use an interactive whiteboard and screen sharing so that I can explain concepts better.
As a student, I want my tutoring sessions to be recorded so that I can review them later.
As a student, I want to pay for tutoring sessions via secure payment methods so that I can complete my bookings.
As a student, I want to receive an invoice after each session so that I can keep track of my expenses.
As a student, I want to leave a review and rating for my tutor so that I can share my feedback.
As a user, I want to receive real-time in-app notifications so that I stay updated on any changes.
As a tutor, I want to view reports of my sessions and earnings so that I can track my performance.
As a tutor, I want to see analytics on my ratings so that I can improve my teaching.

The student must be registered and logged into the system. The student must have access to a list of available courses. The course must be open for application.

1. The student navigates to the course catalog or uses the search function to find the desired course. 2. The student selects the course they are interested in from the list of available courses. 3. The system displays the course details, including the syllabus, schedule, tutor information, and any prerequisites. 4. The student clicks on the "Apply" or "Enroll" button. 5. The system checks if the student meets the prerequisites for the course. If all conditions are met, the process continues. 6. The system confirms the student's enrollment in the course and confirmation email, or notification is sent to the student. 7. The system adds the course details, including the schedule and access information, to the student's dashboard. 8. The student can now access the course materials, forums, and any other resources provided by the tutor.

2.2 System module 2.2.1 Login Enables all users to securely access the system using their registered account credentials.

2.2.7 Payment Manages all financial transactions within the system. This module handles payment creation, confirmation, and processing of refunds. It generates and provides payment invoices to users and validates payment details before approval. Sensitive payment data is encrypted to ensure compliance with PDPA and PCI DSS requirements, protecting user financial information from unauthorized access.

2.2.10 Search Enables tutor discovery by enabling users to system targeted searches based on course, qualifications, ratings, and availability. This module provides filtering and sorting capabilities, receive detailed tutor profiles, and highlights top-rated tutors to improve course selection efficiency.
2.3 Design and Implementation Constraints The Online Tutoring System must adhere to several constraints to ensure it is feasible, maintainable, and compliant with industry standards.
Accessibility: Follow Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 to ensure usability by individuals with disabilities.
Human Resources: Availability of skilled developers, designers, and support staff may limit development pace and scope. Consider outsourcing to mitigate this constraint.
Data Security: Encrypt all user data in transit and at rest to protect against unauthorized access. Conduct regular security audits and vulnerability assessments.
Scalability and Performance: Design the interface to support future expansion and optimize for fast loading times and smooth interactions, especially during live sessions.
Resource Availability: Financial, human, and technical resources will be available throughout the project.
Third-Party Services: Third-party services (cloud hosting, payment gateways) will be reliable and uphold SLAs.

The system shall allow new users (students and tutors) to register by providing necessary details like name, email, password, and role.
The system shall send a verification email to confirm the user's email address before account activation.
The system shall allow users to log in using their registered email and password.
The system shall provide a mechanism for users to recover their password via email.
The system shall allow users to view other users' profiles with appropriate privacy controls.
The system shall provide a search function for students to find tutors based on subjects, availability, and ratings.
The system shall allow users to filter and sort tutor search results by price, rating, and experience.
The system shall allow tutors to set their available time slots.
The system shall allow students to book sessions with tutors based on their availability.

4. Functional and Non-Functional Requirements The following requirements define the system's core functionalities and its quality attributes. Functional requirements specify the essential services the system must provide, while non-functional requirements describe characteristics such as performance, usability, security, and reliability. All requirements are based on validated stakeholder input and serve as the basis for system design, development, and testing.

2.2 System module 2.2.1 Login Enables all users to securely access the system using their registered account credentials.

The module manages session initiation and termination, ensuring that users are properly authenticated before accessing other system functions. It also supports password recovery by allowing users to request a reset link and update their credentials. This module serves as the primary gateway for students, tutors, and administrators to interact with the system.

Role: Student, Tutor, Administrators 2.2.3 Course Management Manages the complete lifecycle of course data within the system. This module receives and displays available courses, provides detailed course information, and allows creation, modification, and deletion of course records. It supports uploading course materials including documents, images, and videos, ensuring they are linked to the correct course. All changes are stored in the database and reflected in the course list in real time.

2.2.4 Profile Management Handles user profile data for students and tutors. This module receives and displays user details, supports updating personal information, and manages assigned user roles. It allows are stored in the database and synchronized across the system to ensure consistency.

Role: Student, Tutor, Administrators 2.2.5 Enrollment Manages the process of course registration for students. This module receives enrollment requests, verifies course availability, and prevents duplicate enrollments. It supports cancellation of enrollments and confirms successful registration. It also links confirmed enrollments to the payment module for transaction processing, ensuring accurate records and seamless workflow integration.

Role: Student, Administrators 2.2.6 Videotelephony Facilitates real-time virtual tutoring sessions between students and tutors. This module supports starting and joining live video sessions, requesting device access for camera and microphone, and ending sessions upon completion. It enables session recording upon request and securely stores the recordings for future reference or review. Integrated with the notifications module to send session reminders and real-time alerts.

2.2.7 Payment Manages all financial transactions within the system. This module handles payment creation, confirmation, and processing of refunds. It generates and provides payment invoices to users and validates payment details before approval. Sensitive payment data is encrypted to ensure compliance with PDPA and PCI DSS requirements, protecting user financial information from unauthorized access.

Role: Student, Administrators 2.2.8 Feedback Collects and manages student evaluations of courses and tutors. This module records written feedback, ratings, and verifies submissions to ensure authenticity and relevance. It calculates and provides the average rating for each tutor or course, supporting quality monitoring and continuous improvement.

2.2.10 Search Enables tutor discovery by enabling users to system targeted searches based on course, qualifications, ratings, and availability. This module provides filtering and sorting capabilities, receive detailed tutor profiles, and highlights top-rated tutors to improve course selection efficiency.

Role: Student, Tutor, Administrators 2.2.11 Notification Manages notification delivery and reminder scheduling for system events. Supports sending email notifications, issuing reminders for upcoming sessions, receiving notification history, and updating notification statuses to maintain user awareness of important activities.
2.3 Design and Implementation Constraints The Online Tutoring System must adhere to several constraints to ensure it is feasible, maintainable, and compliant with industry standards.
2.3.1 Regulatory and Compliance Constraints The platform must comply with legal and ethical requirements, particularly in Malaysia and Southeast Asia:
Accessibility: Follow Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 to ensure usability by individuals with disabilities.
Human Resources: Availability of skilled developers, designers, and support staff may limit development pace and scope. Consider outsourcing to mitigate this constraint.
Data Security: Encrypt all user data in transit and at rest to protect against unauthorized access. Conduct regular security audits and vulnerability assessments.
Scalability and Performance: Design the interface to support future expansion and optimize for fast loading times and smooth interactions, especially during live sessions.
Compliance and Regulations: Platform will comply with current regulations in Malaysia and Southeast Asia.
Resource Availability: Financial, human, and technical resources will be available throughout the project.
Third-Party Services: Third-party services (cloud hosting, payment gateways) will be reliable and uphold SLAs.
2.4.2 Dependencies The following dependencies must be managed to ensure the project's success:

The system shall allow new users (students and tutors) to register by providing necessary details like name, email, password, and role.
The system shall send a verification email to confirm the user's email address before account activation.
The system shall allow users to log in using their registered email and password.
The system shall provide a mechanism for users to recover their password via email.
The system shall allow users to view other users' profiles with appropriate privacy controls.
The system shall provide a search function for students to find tutors based on subjects, availability, and ratings.
The system shall allow users to filter and sort tutor search results by price, rating, and experience.
The system shall allow tutors to set their available time slots.
The system shall allow students to book sessions with tutors based on their availability.

All requirements are based on validated stakeholder input and serve as the basis for system design, development, and testing.

Software Requirements Gathering and Specification from Stakeholders 1. Introduction In software engineering, the process of gathering requirements from stakeholders is a crucial step in developing a successful software system. A Software Requirements Specification (SRS) serves as a formal agreement between stakeholders and developers, outlining what the system will do and under what constraints. This document illustrates the process of gathering, analyzing, and specifying both functional and non-functional requirements using a Library Management System as an example.

2. Stakeholder Identification Stakeholders are individuals or organizations who have an interest in the system. Identifying and engaging stakeholders early ensures that all perspectives are considered. For the Library Management System, the primary stakeholders include:

The software engineer employs interviews, questionnaires, document analysis, and observation to gather both explicit and implicit requirements. Prototypes and use cases may also be used to validate understanding. The elicited requirements are documented and refined through iterative discussions.

4. Functional Requirements Functional requirements define what the system should do its specific behavior and functionalities. For the Library Management System, the following functional requirements were gathered from stakeholders:
FR1 The system shall allow members to search for books by title, author, category, or ISBN.
FR2 The system shall allow members to borrow and return books using their library accounts.
FR3 The system shall enable administrators to add, edit, or remove books from the catalog.
FR4 The system shall send automated email notifications for overdue books.
FR5 The system shall generate usage and inventory reports for administrators.
The system shall provide a response time of less than 3 seconds for search queries.
The system shall ensure data confidentiality through role-based access control.
The system shall be available 99.5% of the time, excluding scheduled maintenance.
The user interface shall be intuitive and comply with accessibility standards (WCAG 2.1).
The system shall support up to 500 concurrent users without performance degradation.
NFR1 The system shall provide a response time of less than 3 seconds for search queries.
NFR2 The system shall ensure data confidentiality through role-based access control.
NFR3 The system shall be available 99.5% of the time, excluding scheduled maintenance.
NFR4 The user interface shall be intuitive and comply with accessibility standards (WCAG 2.1).
NFR5 The system shall support up to 500 concurrent users without performance degradation.

6. Requirement Validation and Documentation Once functional and non-functional requirements are gathered, they are validated through reviews, stakeholder meetings, and prototypes. Each requirement is checked for clarity, feasibility, and traceability. The approved requirements are then documented in the SRS, forming the foundation for system design, testing, and maintenance. Validation ensures that the system developed aligns with stakeholder needs and expectations.

The customer shall be able to search for food items by category.
The system shall allow customers to add multiple items to the shopping cart.

Course and Assignment System o Enables administrators to review and approve course creation requests. o Allows tutors to manage course content and evaluate student assignments. o Supports students in accessing enrolled courses and submitting assignments for evaluation.

Session Coordination o Manages scheduling of live tutoring sessions, dispatches automated reminders, and synchronizes calendars. o Provides virtual classroom functionalities, including video conferencing, whiteboard tools, and screen sharing for interactive lessons. o Initiates and manages payment and refund requests based on session bookings and cancellations. o Performs internal validation of transaction data prior to forwarding requests to external payment gateways.

Analytics and Moderation o Tracks key performance indicators such as attendance records and assignment outcomes. o Provides administrators with dashboards for monitoring system statistics and moderating user-generated content.
2.2 System module 2.2.1 Login Enables all users to securely access the system using their registered account credentials.

The module manages session initiation and termination, ensuring that users are properly authenticated before accessing other system functions. It also supports password recovery by allowing users to request a reset link and update their credentials. This module serves as the primary gateway for students, tutors, and administrators to interact with the system.

Role: Student, Tutor, Administrators 2.2.3 Course Management Manages the complete lifecycle of course data within the system. This module receives and displays available courses, provides detailed course information, and allows creation, modification, and deletion of course records. It supports uploading course materials including documents, images, and videos, ensuring they are linked to the correct course. All changes are stored in the database and reflected in the course list in real time.

2.2.4 Profile Management Handles user profile data for students and tutors. This module receives and displays user details, supports updating personal information, and manages assigned user roles. It allows are stored in the database and synchronized across the system to ensure consistency.

Role: Student, Tutor, Administrators 2.2.5 Enrollment Manages the process of course registration for students. This module receives enrollment requests, verifies course availability, and prevents duplicate enrollments. It supports cancellation of enrollments and confirms successful registration. It also links confirmed enrollments to the payment module for transaction processing, ensuring accurate records and seamless workflow integration.

Role: Student, Administrators 2.2.6 Videotelephony Facilitates real-time virtual tutoring sessions between students and tutors. This module supports starting and joining live video sessions, requesting device access for camera and microphone, and ending sessions upon completion. It enables session recording upon request and securely stores the recordings for future reference or review. Integrated with the notifications module to send session reminders and real-time alerts.

2.2.7 Payment Manages all financial transactions within the system. This module handles payment creation, confirmation, and processing of refunds. It generates and provides payment invoices to users and validates payment details before approval. Sensitive payment data is encrypted to ensure compliance with PDPA and PCI DSS requirements, protecting user financial information from unauthorized access.

Role: Student, Administrators 2.2.8 Feedback Collects and manages student evaluations of courses and tutors. This module records written feedback, ratings, and verifies submissions to ensure authenticity and relevance. It calculates and provides the average rating for each tutor or course, supporting quality monitoring and continuous improvement.

2.2.10 Search Enables tutor discovery by enabling users to system targeted searches based on course, qualifications, ratings, and availability. This module provides filtering and sorting capabilities, receive detailed tutor profiles, and highlights top-rated tutors to improve course selection efficiency.

Role: Student, Tutor, Administrators 2.2.11 Notification Manages notification delivery and reminder scheduling for system events. Supports sending email notifications, issuing reminders for upcoming sessions, receiving notification history, and updating notification statuses to maintain user awareness of important activities.
2.3 Design and Implementation Constraints The Online Tutoring System must adhere to several constraints to ensure it is feasible, maintainable, and compliant with industry standards.
2.3.1 Regulatory and Compliance Constraints The platform must comply with legal and ethical requirements, particularly in Malaysia and Southeast Asia:
Accessibility: Follow Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 to ensure usability by individuals with disabilities.
Compatibility: Ensure compatibility with various devices, operating systems, and web browsers. Conduct thorough testing across different platforms.
Scalability: Design the system to handle increasing users and sessions without compromising performance. Use scalable cloud services and efficient database management.
Human Resources: Availability of skilled developers, designers, and support staff may limit development pace and scope. Consider outsourcing to mitigate this constraint.
User Interface (UI) Design: Provide an intuitive and user-friendly interface for users with varying technical expertise. Ensure clear navigation, responsive design, and accessible features.
Data Security: Encrypt all user data in transit and at rest to protect against unauthorized access. Conduct regular security audits and vulnerability assessments.
Consistency and Responsiveness: Ensure a cohesive look and feel across the platform with a fully responsive design for desktops, tablets, and smartphones.
Scalability and Performance: Design the interface to support future expansion and optimize for fast loading times and smooth interactions, especially during live sessions.
Compliance and Regulations: Platform will comply with current regulations in Malaysia and Southeast Asia.
Resource Availability: Financial, human, and technical resources will be available throughout the project.
Third-Party Services: Third-party services (cloud hosting, payment gateways) will be reliable and uphold SLAs.

Non-functional requirements were validated through performance testing, scalability and load testing, usability evaluations, accessibility audits, security assessments, reliability monitoring, and compliance checks.

Through this validation, it is demonstrated that: o Completeness Every functional requirement (FR-01 to FR-23) and non-functional requirement (NFR-01 to NFR-19) has been mapped to at least one acceptance test (AT-01 to AT-41). This guarantees that no requirement is left unvalidated, and the overall scope of the system is fully covered during testing. o Consistency The validation approach ensures that no conflicting requirements or contradictory validation methods exist across the specification. Terminology and test criteria are applied uniformly, minimizing ambiguity and reducing the risk of misinterpretation during implementation or testing. o Traceability Each requirement is linked directly to its corresponding acceptance test, establishing clear bidirectional traceability. This allows stakeholders and developers to track requirements from elicitation through analysis, specification, implementation, and validation, ensuring end-to-end verification throughout the software lifecycle.

The student and tutor's updated profile information is saved in the system. The system provides appropriate error messages, and the user's previous profile data remains intact in case of update failure.
Description: Allows student and tutor to view and update their personal profiles on the online tutoring system. This includes updating personal information, contact details, and profile pictures.
Pre-Condition: The student and tutor must be registered and logged into the system.
The system provides appropriate error messages, and the user's previous profile data remains intact in case of update failure.

5. The system allows the students and tutor to update personal information, such as name, email, contact details, educational 6. The students and tutor complete the updates and clicks the "Save" button.
1. Users can only update his own profiles and cannot access or modify other users' profiles.
Business Rules: 1. Users can only update his own profiles and cannot access or modify other users' profiles.
Allow a student to apply for a course after searching for available courses.
The student must be registered and logged into the system. The student must have access to a list of available courses. The course must be open for application.

1. The student navigates to the course catalog or uses the search function to find the desired course. 2. The student selects the course they are interested in from the list of available courses. 3. The system displays the course details, including the syllabus, schedule, tutor information, and any prerequisites. 4. The student clicks on the "Apply" or "Enroll" button. 5. The system checks if the student meets the prerequisites for the course. If all conditions are met, the process continues. 6. The system confirms the student's enrollment in the course and confirmation email, or notification is sent to the student. 7. The system adds the course details, including the schedule and access information, to the student's dashboard. 8. The student can now access the course materials, forums, and any other resources provided by the tutor.
Description: Allow a student to apply for a course after searching for available courses.
Pre-Condition: The student must be registered and logged into the system.
Basic Path: 1. The student navigates to the course catalog or uses the search function to find the desired course.
8. The student can now access the course materials, forums, and any other resources provided by the tutor.

1. Students must have a valid and authorized account to apply for courses. 2. The system should validate course availability in real-time to prevent overbooking. 3. Course applications should be processed in the order they are received to ensure fairness.
Alternative Paths: 1a. Search Error 4a. Student account Invalid 5a. Network Connection Error Business Rules: 1.
2. The system should validate course availability in real-time to prevent overbooking.
The student and tutor must have compatible devices with internet access, webcam, microphone, and speakers. A tutoring session must be scheduled and accepted by both parties.
Pre-Condition: The student and tutor must have compatible devices with internet access, webcam, microphone, and speakers.

Allows students to make a payment for a course they wish to enroll in. This use case extends to a refund mechanism in case the payment needs to be refunded and includes a confirmation step to confirm the payment.
Student have online pay method. Student under 12 years of age require parental assistance with tuition fees.
Send receipts to registered student emails to receive any notifications. System will record their payment history to his dashboard (Payment).
Use Case Name: Payment Actors: Student(primary) and Admin(secondly) Description: Allows students to make a payment for a course they wish to enroll in.
Pre-Condition: Student have online pay method.
System will record their payment history to his dashboard (Payment).

1. Payment must be completed before enrollment in the course is confirmed. 2. Confirmation of payment must include details such as course name, payment amount, transaction ID, and date.

2. Confirmation of payment must include details such as course name, payment amount, transaction ID, and date.
Allows students to provide feedback on their courses. This feedback can be given anonymously if desired.
1. Anonymous feedback must still comply with community guidelines. 2. The system should ensure that the feedback cannot be traced back to the student to protect their anonymity.

Use Case Name: Feedback Actors: Student(primary), Tutor(secondary) and Admin(tertiary) Description: Allows students to provide feedback on their courses. This feedback can be given anonymously if desired.
2. The system should ensure that the feedback cannot be traced back to the student to protect their anonymity.

The student and tutor choose the type of support needed ex: technical issue, academic help, account problem. 3. The students and tutor complete a form or chat interface with relevant details about their issue, including description of the problem or question and any relevant attachments. 4. The students and tutor submit the form or request through the system. 5. The system confirms receipt of the support request with a confirmation message or email, providing a reference number or estimated response time. 6. The support team reviews the request, categorizes it, and prioritizes it based on urgency and type.

SDMSTM Synergy Distributed Meeting Scheduler 1. Introduction Consider the following scenario A mid-size Consulting company with 80 employees working in the Knowledge management services and handling 20 clients. As the delivery date of some of the projects comes closer imagine the number of meeting that these employees have to handle at a time with an average of 7 participants in each meeting? Imagine yourself being the meetings coordinator for couple of projects?

Scheduling a meeting really is not as simple as it looks, even with scheduling software. A lot of judgment is involved, and there's a real sense of propriety required. In bringing any group of people together, there are so many factors to take into account. This domain is a complex one due to factors such as uncertainty, numerous stakeholders, and potential disturbances. Complexity would increase as more participants were added, or different components were automated. Decisions about where the meeting is held are important as well, and very political. For some meetings, a simple announcement will do. For others, participants will need to be polled for their availability and then confirmed later.

1.1. Purpose The purpose of this Requirements Elicitation document is to provide a clear understanding as to what actually he is SDMSTM system and to identify the critical requirements essential for the project s successful completion. This document provides an abstract overview of the SDMSTM system and provides a general overview of the entire project. However, the architectural and detail design is outside the scope of this document, but will be covered in the Software Requirements Specification document.

This document will be used to organize our team s project plan and deliverables. This document explains our team architecture, our team s initial understanding of the user needs. It will assist our team in understanding the system specifications and analyze the critical aspects of our project. It will allow the project management and development group to grasp the high level details delivered to the end user. This document will briefly discuss the stakeholders involved in the development, documents will show how our team was divided to handle the multiple stakeholders, the sources of the requirements, provide an informal preliminary requirements description, and address any issues encountered while transforming the requirements.

1.3. Definitions, acronyms and abbreviations Agenda A list of topics (and optionally names of persons to lead discussions with optional durations) to be discussed, reviewed, or decided upon at a meeting date range Range of dates acceptable for the proposed meeting duration The time span of a proposed meeting location The physical location of a proposed meeting including building and room number and possibly including the country, state, city. meeting initiator A person who starts the meeting scheduling process who initiates a meeting proposal meeting proposal An invitation to a meeting including the meeting topic, date range, and duration that is sent to a list of potential meeting participants meeting topic The theme of or reason for the meeting potential meeting participant A person who has been invited to a proposed meeting that has not either accepted ( will attend ) nor refused ( will not attend ) propose a meeting To suggest or to decide a meeting is needed required equipment Additional equipment, typically audio-visual equipment, needed in support of the meeting virtual meeting A meeting simultaneously held at multiple remote locations, e.g. teleconferencing will attend A state of a meeting invitation by an individual potential meeting participant indicating that the individual will attend the meeting will not attend A state of a meeting invitation by an individual potential meeting participant indicating that the individual will not attend the meeting Location manager In charge of the location where meeting is scheduled Resource manager In charge of the hardware equipments needed for the meeting.

1.5. Overview The SDMSTM system is a web-based meeting scheduler system that efficiently schedules a meetings by determine the available resources necessary for the meeting to be initiated. This system supports the organization in scheduling meetings by determining each meeting s request, date and location.

1. Section 1 (this section) provides an overview of the entire SRS document 2. Section 2 gives a description of the general factors that affect the product that will be produced based on this SRS. It includes product perspective and General capabilities, General constraints, User characteristics, Operational environment and assumptions and dependencies of the product.

End users Meeting attendees Meeting schedulers/initiators Project management teams Requirement engineers System Developers Maintenance team Network support group Testers 2.2. Team Architecture During our initial meetings, we reviewed the documents provided by Synergysoft: the initial requirement summary and reports from other consulting firms who had conducted prior research on behalf of Synergysoft. With Synergysoft's permission, we were able to reuse much of the work from earlier teams; this significantly aided our ability to meet the condensed schedule.

Team Role Played Primary Functions Performed Member Customer World: (cid:122) Initial Requirement Analysis ABHISHEK End-user/Buyer GOYAL NIKITA Developer World: (cid:122) Requirement Issues PATEL, Programmer, SMARAK Consultant BHUYAN Management World: (cid:122) Process MANISH Project Manager BANSAL, Product Manager ANURAG MAHAJAN - 7 -

Meeting Initiation The meeting initiator issues a meeting request by inviting all potential meeting attendees for a meeting based on the meeting s agenda. An initiator can be one of the participants or some representative, such as a secretary.
Meeting Conflicts A strong conflict occurs when no data can be found within the date range and outside all exclusion sets.
A weak date conflict occurs when dates can be found within the date range and outside all exclusion sets, but no date can be found at the intersection of all preference sets.

Meeting Conflict Resolution If a conflict occurs while generating a meeting, the system shall notify the initiator and ask to o Notify a participant to remove a date from his exclusive set, o Propose a participant with low importance level to withdraw from the meeting, o Propose a participant to extend his preference set. o Propose the initiator to cancel the meeting.

If none of the proposed locations can meet the equipment requirements while making a meeting schedule, the system should inform the initiator. The initiator can propose other locations and start the scheduling process again or cancel the meeting and inform all of the participants about that.

SDMSTM Synergy Distributed Meeting Scheduler System Functional Requirements Description The system shall monitor meetings especially when they are held in a distributed manner like when the participants are located at different location and communicate to each other through virtual networks. To monitor the meeting The system will create the log of all the messages exchanged between the participants so that it s easy for meeting initiator to monitor the meeting planning proceedings.

When planning meetings, the system shall take into account all constraints that are expressed by the meeting participants Each date that the meeting participant can attend shall be added to the preference set Each date that the meeting participant cannot attend shall be added to the exclusion set If a user changes their constraints, the SDMS shall rearrange the meeting to accommodate this change The user s preference set, exclusion set, and preferred location shall be changed before a meeting date/location is proposed by the meeting initiator.

External constraints shall be considered after a meeting date and location have been proposed. For example, if a high priority meeting needs to be accommodated, a lower priority meeting may be changed or cancelled or If a geographical disaster occurs which need to reschedule the meeting then the proposed meeting is cancelled.

All interactions between the meeting participants will be managed. There shall be means to communicate the message by participant. There shall be provision to invoke the participants not taking part in communication. The process of negotiation will also be managed. Moreover the reliability of communication will be monitored.
Easiness:--The system should be usable by the non-experts. The user should be able to operate on the functionality easily.

PERFORMANCE :: -- The elapsed time between the user sending request for meeting and the date and location set should be minimal i.e. the user should not wonder whether he has submitted the request or not. Lower bound should be fixed between determination of meeting date and actual meeting EXTENSIBILITY: -- The system should be able to handle explicit priorities among dates in preference sets. It should handle explicit dependencies between meeting date and meeting location. The system should provide provision to participant for his replacement by other person at the meeting.

PRIVACY: -- Privacy rules should be enforced a non-privileged participant should not be aware of constraints stated by other participants. The system should accommodate as much decentralized requests as possible. Therefore, any authorized user should be able to request a meeting independently of his/her whereabouts CUSTOMIZABLE::-- The system shall be customizable to two ways(1) Private (2) Professional meetings these are characterized by different restrictions on the time period that may be allocated (e.g. meeting during office hours, private activities during leisure time).

FLEXIBLE: -- Rescheduling of a meeting should be done dynamically and with as much flexibility as possible. Also, the system should be flexible enough to accommodate evolving data (e.g. the sets of concerned participants may be varying; the address at which a participant can be reached may be varying, etc.).
6 conflicts can be resolved in several ways PROBLEM: the statement fails to tell which method should be given preference in resolving the conflict over the other.
PROBLEM: Should the meeting initiator only resort to expanding the date range when all the important participants can t attend, or should this be considered for every participant?
Option 1: The date range shall be expanded only when most of the important participants can t attend.
Solution: option 1 Reason: The meeting can never be a success if most of the important participants are not a part of it.

SDMSTM Synergy Distributed Meeting Scheduler AMBIGUOUS 1 To get replies even from participant not reacting promptly PROBLEM: the above statement fails to define how we can measure the activeness Of the participant. Moreover the statement fails to signify how to increase the involvement of the participant.

OPTION1: drop the statement OPTION2: add more statements SOLUTION: OPTION2 REASON: removing ambiguity and misinterpretation INCORRECT IDENTIFICATION 1 meeting scheduler system must in general handle several meeting requests in parallel PROBLEM: - handling several requests at the same time is a non functional characteristic which cannot be stated as a functional requirement of the system OPTION 1 add the above statement as the non functional attribute SOLUTION: OPTION 1 REASON: the above requirement is an important characteristic which cannot be ignored and should be correctly stated.

SDMSTM Synergy Distributed Meeting Scheduler 2 meeting requests can be competing when they overlap in time or space. Concurrency thus must be managed PROBLEM:-concurrency is a non functional requirement .it cannot be implemented functional thus is wrongly stated as functional requirement OPTION 1 add the above statement as the non functional attribute SOLUTION: OPTION 1 REASON: the above requirement is an important characteristic which cannot be ignored and should be correctly stated CONTRADICTION 1 the amount of interaction among the participants should be kept minimal and re- planning of a meeting should be done as dynamically and with much flexibility as possible , to get replies from participants not reacting promptly PROBLEM: the above statements are contradictory stated in the requirements. We want that the re- planning of the meeting should be done as dynamically as possible which means there is no stored procedure for that moreover the policies for conflict resolution requires interaction among the participants so for more flexibility the no of interaction will increase. Similarly for getting replies from participants not reacting promptly it requires that no of interaction among participant s increases.

OPTION 1 remove the constraint the amount of interaction among the participants should be kept minimal OPTION 2 remove the constraint re-planning of a meeting should be done as dynamically and with much flexibility as possible SOLUTION OPTION 1 REASON: the option1 is much better to implement than option2 as non functionality point of view.

SOFTWARE REQUIREMENTS SPECIFICATION (SRS) FOR STUDENT INFORMATION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM 1. INTRODUCTION The student management system can handle all the details about a student. The details include college details, course details, student personal details, academic details etc., the student 1.1 PURPOSE This SRS Document contains the complete software requirements for the Online Student Information Management System (OS I MS) and describes the design decisions, architectural design and the detailed design needed to implement the system. It provides the visibility in the design and provides information needed for software support. New reliable and fast school/college management software with the great customers support. It'll help you with your daily school/college management routines.

1.2 SCOPE Online Student Information Management System is developing for general purpose and used to replace old paper work system and PUMS. OSIMS is to build upon the existing information system PUMS in order to efficiently provide student information to teachers and school/college administration. This increase in efficiency of result making, provide result to parents, give feedback to student, finally, publication and email student result. It provides a mechanism to edit the student information form which makes the system flexible.

2. OVERALL DESCRIPTION The student management system allows authorized members to access the records of academically registered students. It can be used in various educational institutes across the globe and simplifies working of institutes.

2.1. Product Perspective The proposed system shall be developed using client/server architecture and be compatible with Microsoft Windows Operating System. The front end of the system will be developed using Visual Basic 6.0 and backend will be developed using MS SQL Server 2000.

2.1.2. User Interfaces The ONSMS will have following user-friendly and menu driven interfaces b) School/college Details: to maintain school/college details. c) Programme Details: to maintain programme details. d) Scheme Details : to maintain scheme details of a programme. e) Paper Details: to maintain paper details of a scheme for a particular programme g) Faculty Details : to maintain the faculty details.
2.1.3. Hardware Interfaces b) Support for printer (dot matrix, deskjet, laserjet) c) Computer systems will be in the networked environment as it is a multi-user system.

2.1.4. Software Interfaces b) Microsoft Visual Basic 6.0 for designing front-end c) MS SQL Server 2000 for backend d) PLATEFORM : JAVA LANGUAGE e) INTEGRATED DEVELOPMENT ENVIRONMENT(IDE):ECLIPSE 2.1.5. Communication Interfaces Connections to the system will be over TCP/IP connection.
2.1.7. Site Adaptation Requirements The terminal at client site will have to support the hardware and software interfaces specified in the section 2.1.3 and 2.1.4 respectively.

2.2. PRODUCT FUNCTIONS The ONSMS will allow access only to authorized users with specific roles (System administrator, Faculty and Student). Depending upon the user s role, he/she will be able to A summary of major functions that the URS will perform A login facility for enabling only authorized access to the system.
System administrator will be able to add, modify or delete programme, school/college, scheme, paper and login information.
Students will be able to add/modify his/her details and register for papers to be studied in the current semester.
System administrator/Faculty will be able to generate reports.

The delete operation is available only to the administrator. To reduce the complexity of the system, there is no check on delete operation. Hence, administrator should be very careful before deletion of any record and he/she will be responsible for data consistency.
2.5 ASSUMPTIONS AND DEPENDENCIES The login Id and password must be created by system administrator and communicated to the concerned user confidentially to avoid unauthorized access to the system.
User (admin, student and teachers) shall be able to load the Login Module in the
internet browser. The LM shall support the user to log into the system. The login panel shall
be masked with symbols when the user types. It shall also contain a button labeled as Login.
When the user clicks on Login button the username and password will be verified by database
administrator and then only the user will able to use the system functions.
After successful login, user shall be able to continue navigating through the website and view
shall be able to update and maintain their profile, such as changing password and personal
Users who visit SMS but have not registered, are able to navigate through the system. Users shall
be able to view currently held events & upcoming institute schedule. Users shall be able to view
school/college timings and their faculties information. Users are able to register themselves as
registered users, by clicking on the register now button.
After successful login, system shall display administrative functions. Administrative functions
shown shall be add and update. When administrator clicks on the add button, system shall
display a section where administrator can add new student details, remove unused student details
and many more. When administrator clicks on update button, system shall display a section
where administrator can update student details and schedule of lecture which are currently stored

1.1 Purpose The purpose of this document is to give a detailed description of the requirements for the Amazing development of system. It will also explain system constraints, interface and interactions with other external applications. This document is primarily intended to be proposed to a customer for its approval 1.2 Scope The Amazing Lunch Indicator is a GPS-based mobile application which helps people to find the closest restaurants based on the user s current position and other specification like price, restaurant type, dish and more. The application should be free to download from either a mobile phone application store or similar services.

Restaurant owners can provide their restaurant information using the web-portal. This information will act as the bases for the search results displayed to the user. An administrator also uses the web-portal in order to administer the system and keep the information accurate. The administrator can, for instance, verify restaurant owners and manage user information.

Furthermore, the software needs both Internet and GPS connection to fetch and display results. All system information is maintained in a database, which is located on a web-server. The software also interacts with the GPS-Navigator software which is required to be an already installed application on the user s mobile phone. By using the GPS-Navigator, users can view desired restaurants on a map and be navigated to them. The application also has the capability of representing both summary and detailed information about the restaurants.
An installed software on mobile phone which could provide GPS connection and data, show locations on map and find paths from current position to defined destination
The level at which good success can be claimed contained in a PLanguage statement [2]

and admin GPS Global Positioning System GPS-Navigator An installed software on mobile phone which could provide GPS connection and data, show locations on map and find paths from current position to defined destination Application Store An installed application on mobile phone which helps user to find new compatible applications with mobile phone platform and download them from Internet Stakeholder Any person who has interaction with the system who is not a developer.

DESC Description RAT Rational DEP Dependency TAG A unique, persistent identifier contained in a PLanguage statement [2] GIST A short, simple description of the concept contained in a PLanguage statement [2] SCALE The scale of measure used by the requirement contained in a PLanguage statement [2] METER The process or device used to establish location on a SCALE contained in a PLanguage statement [2] MUST The minimum level required to avoid failure contained in a PLanguage statement [2] PLAN The level at which good success can be claimed contained in a PLanguage statement [2] WISH A desirable level of achievement that may not be attainable through available means contained in a PLanguage statement [2] DEFINED The official definition of a term contained in a PLanguage statement [2] [1] IEEE Software Engineering Standards Committee, IEEE Std 830-1998, IEEE Recommended Practice for Software Requirements Specifications , October 20, 1998.

The third chapter provides the requirements specification in detailed terms and a description of the different system interfaces. Different specification techniques are used in order to specify the requirements more precisely for different audiences.

2. Overall description This section will give an overview of the whole system. The system will be explained in its context to show how the system interacts with other systems and introduce the basic functionality of it. It will also describe what type of stakeholders that will use the system and what functionality is available for each type. At last, the constraints and assumptions for the system will be presented.

2.1 Product perspective This system will consist of two parts: one mobile application and one web portal. The mobile application will be used to find restaurants and view information about them while the web portal will be used for managing the information about the restaurants and the system as a whole.

The mobile application will need to communicate to a GPS application within the mobile phone, which in turn communicates with a physical GPS device to find the mobile application with locations of both the user and the restaurants and the distance between them, but it will also provide maps and the functionality to display the application s data on the map. The functionality provided by the GPS will be embedded into the application in order for the user to be able to use the functions in the application in a seamlessly manner.

Since this is a data-centric product it will need somewhere to store the data. For that, a database will be used. Both the mobile application and web portal will communicate with the database, however in slightly different ways. The mobile application will only use the database to get data while the web portal will also add and modify data. All of the database communication will go over the Internet.

2.2 Product functions With the mobile application, the users will be able to search for restaurants. The result will be based on the criteria the user inputs. There are several search criteria and it will be possible for the administrator of the system to manage the options for those criteria that have that.

The result of the search will be viewed either in a list view or in a map view, depending on what criteria included in the search. The list view will have one list item for each restaurant matching the search criteria and show a small part of the restaurant information so the user can identify the restaurant. The

map view will show each restaurant location as a pin on the map as well as the user s own location. In both views the users will be able to either select a restaurant as target destination or get information how to get there, or view the information of a specific restaurant.
The web portal will provide functionality to manage the system and the restaurant information. It will also provide information about the system, for example show when there is a new update.

The mobile application users can only use the application to find a restaurant. This means that the user have to be able to search for restaurants, choose a restaurant from that search and then navigate to it. In order for the users to get a relevant search result there are multiple criteria the users can specify and all results matches all of those.

The restaurant owners will not use the mobile application but the web portal instead. There they will manage the information about their restaurant, for example a description of the restaurant, contact information and their menu.

The administrators also only interact with the web portal. They are managing the overall system so there is no incorrect information within it. The administrator can manage the information for each restaurant as well as the options for both the mobile application users and the restaurant owners.

2.4 Constraints The mobile application is constrained by the system interface to the GPS navigation system within the mobile phone. Since there are multiple system and multiple GPS manufacturers, the interface will most likely not be the same for every one of them. Also, there may be a difference between what navigation features each of them provide.

Both the web portal and the mobile application will be constrained by the capacity of the database. Since the database is shared between both application it may be forced to queue incoming requests and therefor increase the time it takes to fetch data.

2.5 Assumptions and dependencies One assumption about the product is that it will always be used on mobile phones that have enough performance. If the phone does not have enough hardware resources available for the application, for example the users might have allocated them with other applications, there may be scenarios where the application does not work as intended or even at all.

3.1 External interface Requirements This section provides a detailed description of all inputs into and outputs from the system. It also gives a description of the hardware, software and communication interfaces and provides basic prototypes of the user interface.

3.1.1 User interfaces default one. The sorting header allows the user to sort the results according to price, restaurant name, distance, restaurant type and specific dish. Each result item includes information about the restaurants, a the restaurant. There is also a filtering option, where the user can choose to filter the results by increasing information link which provides a more detailed description of the restaurant, as mentioned for the list view. The same filtering option, as for the list view, is included in the map view.

restaurant owner should be able to register on the web-portal in order to log in and manage the restaurant information. An administrator should also be able to log in to the web-portal where he/she can administer the system by for instance editing restaurant or user information.

3.2.1 User Class 1 - The User 3.2.1.1 Functional requirement 1.1 ID: FR1 TITLE: Download mobile application DESC: A user should be able to download the mobile application through either an application store or similar service on the mobile phone. The application should be free to download.

DEP: None 3.2.1.2 Functional requirement 1.2 ID: FR2 TITLE: Download and notify users of new releases manually. The download of the new release should be done through the mobile phone in the same way as downloading the mobile application.

DEP: FR1 3.2.1.3 Functional requirement 1.3 ID: FR3 TITLE: User registration - Mobile application DESC: Given that a user has downloaded the mobile application, then the user should be able to register through the mobile application. The user must provide user-name, password and e-mail address. The user can choose to provide a regularly used phone number.
RAT: In order for a user to register on the mobile application.
3.2.1.4 Functional requirement 1.4 ID: FR4 TITLE: User log-in - Mobile application DESC: Given that a user has registered, then the user should be able to log in to the mobile application.
DEP: FR1, FR3 3.2.1.5 Functional requirement 1.5 ID: FR5 TITLE: Retrieve password DESC: Given that a user has registered, then the user should be able to retrieve his/her password by e- mail.

DEP: FR1 3.2.1.6 Functional requirement 1.6 ID: FR6 TITLE: Mobile application - Search The search options are Price, Destination, Restaurant type and Specific dish. There should also be a free- text search option. A user should be able to select multiple search options in one search.
RAT: In order for a user to search for a restaurant.
DEP: FR4 3.2.1.7 Functional requirement 1.7 ID: FR7 TITLE: Mobile application - Search result in a map view DESC:
Search results can be viewed on a map. On the map, the relevant and closest restaurants according to the user s position are shown.
There should be maximally 100 results displayed. The map view should have a default zoom.
The map view should include a button that, when selected, should display different filtering options in a filtering menu.
3.2.1.8 Functional requirement 1.8 ID: FR8 TITLE: Mobile application - Search result in a list view DESC:
Search results can be viewed in a list. Each element in the list represents a specific restaurant.

Each element should include the restaurant name, telephone number, type of food, distance according to the user s position, average price, a short two-line description, a link to the There should be maximally 100 results displayed. If the result contains more restaurants than what can be displayed on the screen at one time, the user should be able to scroll through them.
When searching by price the restaurants should be sorted according to the following order:
1. average price 2. distance 3. restaurant type 4. specific dish When searching by a search option, other than price, the restaurants should be sorted according to the following order:
1. distance 2. average price 3. restaurant type 4. specific dish The list view should include a header with different selectable sorting options.
The list view should include a button that, when selected, should display different filtering options in a filtering menu.

DEP: FR6 3.2.1.9 Functional requirement 1.9 ID: FR9 TITLE: Mobile application - Navigation to restaurant DESC: A user should be able to select a pin on a map or an element on a list. When a selection is made, the location of the restaurant should be sent to the mobile phone s GPS-navigation program. The user should then be navigated to the destination. When the destination is reached, a user should be able to go RAT: To navigate a user to a chosen restaurant.

DEP: FR7, FR8 3.2.1.10 Functional requirement 1.10 ID: FR10 TITLE: Mobile application - Switch result view DESC: A user should be able to switch between a map view and a list view for all search options.

DEP: FR7, FR8 3.2.1.12 Functional requirement 1.12 ID: FR12 TITLE: Mobile application - Search by price DESC: A user should be able to input a maximum and a minimum price range. The result is displayed in a list view by default.

DEP: FR8 3.2.1.13 Functional requirement 1.13 ID: FR13 TITLE: Mobile application - Search by destination DESC: A user should be able to input a maximum and a minimum distance, according to his/her position.
